description: From Middle English nave, navye, from Anglo-Norman, Old French navie, from Latin nāvigia < nāvigium, from Latin nāvigō, nāvis (“boat”), from Proto-Indo-European *néh₂us. Compare Ancient Greek ναῦς (naûs, “ship”), Persian ناو‎ (nâv, “boat, warship”), Sanskrit नाव (nāva, “ship”), Old English nōwend (“mariner, sailor”).
Displaced native Old English sċiphere (literally “ship army”).

adjectives.description: navy (comparative more navy, superlative most navy)

entries.meaning: (color) Having the dark blue colour of navy blue.
(military) Belonging to the navy; typical of the navy.
examples: Goodwin was navy through and through.

entries.meaning: (countable) A country's entire sea force, including ships and personnel.
examples: People who get seasick easily shouldn't join the navy.

entries.meaning: (countable) A governmental department in charge of a country's sea force.
(color, countable and uncountable) A dark blue colour, usually called navy blue.
